pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:2.1: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:5.1: 11. The training rule on heavy outer robes
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:6.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:6.2: At that time the nun Thullanandā was a learned reciter, and she was confident and skilled at giving teachings.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:6.3: Just then it was cold and king Pasenadi of Kosala had dressed in an expensive outer robe made of wool. He then went to Thullanandā, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:6.5: And Thullanandā instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:6.8: “Great king, if you wish to give me something, then give me this woolen outer robe.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:6.9: The king gave her his outer robe. He then got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated her with his right side toward her, and left.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:6.11: “These nuns have great desires; they are not content.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:6.12: How can they ask the king for his woolen outer robe?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:7.1: The nuns heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:7.2: and the nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:7.4: “How could Venerable Thullanandā ask the king for his woolen outer robe?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:7.5: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Thullanandā asked for this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:7.8: How can the nun Thullanandā ask the king for his woolen outer robe?
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:7.9: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:7.10: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:8.1: ‘If a nun carries out an exchange to get a heavy outer robe, it is to be worth at most four _kaṁsas_. If she gets one in exchange that is worth more than that, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:9.2: whatever outer robe is used in cold weather.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:10.1: Carries out an exchange to get:
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:11.1: It is to be worth at most four _kaṁsas_:
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:11.2: it may be worth sixteen _kahāpaṇa_ coins.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:12.1: If she gets one in exchange that is worth more than that:
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:12.2: if she asks for one worth more than that, then the effort constitutes wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:12.3: When she obtains it, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:12.4: It is to be relinquished to the Order of nuns, a group, or an individual nun.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:12.5: To be expanded as in Nuns’ Relinquishment 1, {MS.2.2431-2.2435}, with appropriate substitutions.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:12.6: ‘Venerables, this heavy outer robe worth more than four _kaṁsas_ which I got in exchange is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Order.’ …
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:13.1: If it is worth more than four _kaṁsas_, and she perceives it as such, and she gets it in exchange, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:13.2: If it is worth more than four _kaṁsas_, but she is unsure if it is, and she gets it in exchange, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:13.3: If it is worth more than four _kaṁsas_, but she perceives it as worth less than four _kaṁsas_, and she gets it in exchange, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:14.1: If it is worth less than four _kaṁsas_, but she perceives it as worth more than four _kaṁsas_, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:14.2: If it is worth less than four _kaṁsas_, but she is unsure of it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:14.3: If it is worth less than four _kaṁsas_, and she perceives it as worth less than four _kaṁsas_, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:15.2: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11:16.1: The eleventh training rule is finished.
